segments.text: Now, the first series of questions really involve your academic training and your direction towards oceanography, or what directed you towards oceanography.
So would you begin there, please?
OK.
My first background in oceanography came from a background in geophysics where I was at the California Institute of Technology from 1948 to 1952 as an undergraduate.
I started out in physics and then got interested in field work, geophysics, got into geology and geophysics there.
Completed a Bachelor of Science program in 1952.
And about the same time, I started hearing about the oceans in different ways.
I think like most everybody hears about the oceans nowadays too.
And heard also about the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, which wasn't very far from where I lived.
So the summer of, or the spring of 1952, shortly before I was graduating, I went down to talk with a few people down there.
I was given a couple of people's names.
I didn't know anybody down there to talk with and get introduced to what oceanography was all about, particularly in the geophysical side.
And I think I spoke initially down there with Roger Revell, who
kind of nonplussed me with the question, well, what do you want to do?
And I said, well, I'm not sure.
What is there to do in oceanography?

And during a very busy meeting, a scientific meeting down there, which I think was going on with the Institute of Geophysics, I heard some interesting talks, and then Ravel was kind enough to give me an hour or so of his time
after the meeting and asked me this question and listened to my background and hear what I wanted to do in oceanography.
And after that, he steered me over to Russell Raitt, who was a geophysicist there working in seismic refraction.
And I talked with Russ for a while, and he offered me a job for the summer down at Scripps.
So I took it.
summer job, went down for the summer and got involved with some of the instrumentation problems of doing seismic work at sea.

And got a couple of short cruises under my belt that summer with the so-called bottle snatchers, the physical oceanographers who were making hydrographic casts offshore near California, and learned what going to sea was like on a small ship.
at least in the summer outside of California.
The summer went very fast.
And as it turned out, the seismic work I was doing and the instrumentation I was working on with Dr.
Raid was being developed for a cruise that was being started in the fall to go to the South Pacific, one of the first major cruises of Scripps designated Capricorn.
And near the end of the summer, Russ asked me whether I might be interested to go on this cruise, which was four months long, October to February, something like that.
And I thought it over, because during the meanwhile, I had began thinking seriously about getting into graduate school at Scripps for the fall and had applied and was ready to do that.
And Russ suggested I might as well
go on this cruise because that was part of any oceanographer's training program anyway, and that'd be just like going to graduate school.
So I agreed.
And that was sort of my launching point for major oceanography.
I could get into some of the details of that cruise.
Right, right.
What were your impressions as sort of a first-timer on an oceanographic cruise?

Well, I was kind of fascinated by everything, and everything was new, and it, you know, I'd never been out on any major cruise at all in my life, and I was, I guess, you know, having some of the same feelings that maybe a person like Christopher Columbus had about going out to sea.
You know, what's on the other side of the shelf edge out there?
And the first leg of the cruise was from San Diego out to the, I think, Inuit Tower.
In fact, the ship was participating in some of those initial atom bomb tests at that time, 1952.
And they were physical oceanographers and chemists were taking samples and doing some studies of the islands out there.
And Professor Ray was not on the first leg, but I remember the first leg was being headed up by Arthur Maxwell.
who was a graduate student at Scripps at that time, and was my first contact with the people actually doing work at Scripps.
And Art was then doing the heat flow work at Scripps.
I wasn't involved at all.
And he did that as his thesis program.
One of the, some of the first heat flow measurements ever made at sea, which originally got started that same summer with Sir Edward Bullard.
We've probably talked about this already.
So those were kind of exciting days of new instrumentation, new things going on in oceanography, all coming along very suddenly.
And I was just getting into it myself.
So I felt part of that excitement, I think, during the work.
We were going to do new things at sea.
Seismic refraction hadn't been done very much.
And I was participating in that particular program as essentially a technician to help out on that program.
At the same time, we were going out to these coral islands.
I'd never seen coral islands diving, and I was interested in diving and underwater exploration and things of this sort.
So there was a whole diving program on board, for example, to look at coral reefs.
I wasn't a professional diver myself, but I participated in a little bit of that, skin diving and snorkeling, which was part of the attraction to me at that time for oceanography.
It still is to some extent.

So we spent some time out at the islands there and then had a pretty long cruise, four months long, which took us down through the South Pacific Islands, the beautiful weather, kind of South Pacific cruise thing.
But spending most of our time at sea, of course, doing these major seismic progression experiments.
I think we did more refraction work that cruise that had ever been done before anywhere.
a large number of stations, which I can't remember.
And particularly, I remember the people on board who were some of the pioneers in oceanography.
Roger Revelle joined us out after the first transit out.
He wasn't with us on the first flight.
He joined us in a week talk in a bikini, and then was with us for the rest of the cruise, which lasted about three and a half months.
And Russ Ray.
And Walter Monk was with us.
And Martin Johnson, who was one of the first, well, he was co-author of the book, The Oceans.
And he was doing a lot of plankton sampling.
And Walter Monk was kind of doing everything, like he always does.
And I think he was sort of in between some research programs of his own and wanted to go on this cruise, which was really an exciting event.
Oh, and we had Willard Baskin, Bill Baskin, along with us, who is kind of an engineering entrepreneur at sea.
I don't know whether you've talked with him.
No.
He'd be a fascinating person to talk to, too, if you can.
He has a whole story of his own, which is fascinating, but I think I should let him tell it.
Is he here at Wato?
No, he's now in a private firm out in Long Beach, California.
I think he works for the state now, the State Department of Water Resources or something like that in California.
But he still keeps contacts with oceanography.
We have a ship here now that was designed by him.
We just got the Alcoa Sea Probe, which is an aluminum vessel built for
either recovering large objects from the bottom of the ocean, it's got a big derrick on it, or drilling.
And we're about to use it, try to use it, in a research capacity.
But we'll see how that goes in the next year.
Anyway, that was sort of my introduction to oceanography.
I wasn't involved

Arch Maxwell, his measurements, but I was very busy with the marine refraction program and was intending to get more involved with that after the cruise in terms of working up data, interpreting data.
But as it turned out, I got drafted right after the cruise, spent a couple of years in the Army, and
took a little sidetrack at that point, instead of coming directly back into oceanography.

It was clear at Scripps that I think, and something I still tell students, is that we really need to, a person who's serious about oceanography probably doesn't want to major in oceanography as an undergraduate.
Much better to have a basic science background, physics, math, chemistry, engineering, biology.

and then get into a specialty of oceanography, because then you can bring this major field into the field of oceanography and have a much better basic background than you would if you had an oceanographic undergraduate degree.
So I decided I needed a little more background in math and physics, so I went up here to Harvard for a year and a half.
to essentially take more courses in math and physics, sort of get myself brushed up on things after spending a couple of years in the Army.
Yes, enlisted then.
I didn't get sent overseas during the Army, but I was stationed in Maryland in the Chemical Corps.
So it wasn't all bad.
I was very eager to get back into research again.
So I studied for a while under Francis Birch up here at Harvard, who's a geophysicist, solid earth geophysicist.
Not much, he's not very much involved with oceanography, but I took a lot of courses both under him and under other people at Harvard and took a master's degree in Harvard in geophysical sciences.
Then I went back to Scripps in 1956, I think.
Yeah, 1956.
And started a formal graduate program there.
And went through the general courses there.
And after a year, I thought I might get back into the marine refraction work.
But it was clear that there was a lot of interest in diplo measurements.
And see, after Art Maxwell had done his measurements and interpreted them,
And they turned out to be so unusual.
And people thought that should be encouraged.
And I was encouraged to get involved with the heat flow work and see by Russ Raid and others, Roger Abell and others in Scripps at that time.
So I kind of gathered all the equipment that had been left at Scripps.
Art Maxwell had since left Scripps and gone to the ONR, Office of Naval Research, in Washington, DC.
He'd finished all his field work.
Hadn't quite finished writing up his thesis, but he was doing that in Washington.
He wanted somebody to continue that field program.
So I got involved with that and started getting ready for another major cruise
that I went on for another four months.
Those were the days when graduate students really went to sea, as they still do in many institutions, but usually not for so long.
We're a little bit spoiled nowadays.
Well, conditions are different.
We don't have the same emphasis on data gathering as we did at that time.
So I went to sea for four months on the downwind expedition, which was headed by Bill Menard at Scripps, and was essentially a geological, geophysical expedition in 1956.
Is the tape running?
Oh yeah, we're still doing it.
Let's see, it was 56, 57.
That was the international geophysical year, which was, got some momentum from many quarters.
The United States was a big participant.
So oceanography had been enjoying a large increase of funding at that time.
We could support some fairly large expeditions.
And fortunately, I was given some funding and support to get this instrumentation together with the support of other people at Scripps.
and went on this cruise where I managed to, we managed to get quite a few workflow measurements at sea, which formed the basis of my eventual graduate work at Scripps.
And after I got back from that expedition, I was able to start working on the interpretation of the measurements.
It turned out that the distribution of measurements was such that we were concentrating on this major geological feature called the East Pacific Rise in the South Pacific.
Not much was known about that.
It turned out to have very high heat flow and was one of these enigmas before we understood anything about plate tectonics.
Why was that heat flow so high on the East Pacific Rise?
and we mapped it in several places, able to run profiles, and got a general picture of high and low heat flow associated with these major tectonic features on the Earth.
And so I wrote that up in the thesis during the next few years, meanwhile participating in a few other expeditions.
I was, I guess, I was
a field-oriented type person with instrumentation.
That was needed at that time a lot because we had so few measurements to see.
I guess heat flow was also one of the first instrumentation systems to work in the deep sea, electronically.
I think that's true.
When Art Maxwell and Sir Edward Bullard started it, I think it was the first deep sea electronic instrument to work reliably in the deep sea.
I don't know.
There may have been some current meters and things like that.
But electronics just hadn't been developed at all.
Before, we were using vacuum tubes in the instrument, big pressure case, and big instrument, recording on chart paper inside the instrument.
And it was all very bulky and cumbersome.
And it's amazing what electronics has done for us in the ensuing 15 or 20 years.
Just fantastic.
Been a tremendous fallout from the space program for oceanography in many ways.
But that was the job I had to get myself involved with all phases of the research.
Putting the hardware together, making the instrument work,
interpreting the measurements.
So you had to be a jack of all trades in those days.
That's kind of what made you successful.
You could do all things reasonably well and get a thesis out at the same time.
One of the problems then with oceanography was that students tended to spend a long time getting a degree.
They essentially were getting into oceanography as a research person, as a worker.
And they worked for a major research professor that was involved in some field.
But it wasn't a push to get through your degree at that time.
And I could see during the time I was going through the program that I felt some push to get through, perhaps because I was a little older and had gotten in the Army and things of this sort.
And I said, well, I better get this over with and get it over.
I was essentially through in three years, although I didn't get my thesis written up until the fourth year.
That was unusual at Scripps.
It usually took five or six years to get through a graduate program.
Scripps was kind of a funny entity at that time, because it was sort of a research institute separate from the rest of the university.
We were actually part of the University of California in Los Angeles, although we were 200 miles from Los Angeles.
There was no UCSD at that time.
And so I got my degree from UCLA officially, even though I was down in Scripps all the time.
And I had professors on my committee who were at UCLA, geophysicists, not oceanographers, but people who were worried about the solid earth.
And I was worried about the solid earth underneath the oceans.
And so they helped stimulate the whole atmosphere of new ocean exploration.
No one knew anything about the oceans at that time, essentially.
Nothing about sea floor spreading, nothing about plate tectonics.

And I think the heat flow measurements were partially instrumental in developing these new ideas, along with the geomagnetism and other things that you'll probably hear from Jim Hertzberg about and others.
Well, you were saying not much had been done with heat flow then and that primarily that you had thought the instrumentation had developed, excuse me, to the point where it made all of this possible.
Yeah.
Yeah, I think that was sort of the point where
We were benefiting a lot from things like the space program in terms of instruments.
And we were learning how to do things with instruments in the DC much better than we had before.
And I guess I felt, getting into the instrumentation myself, that we had a fairly reliable set of instruments to go to sea.
And so we started to develop this program of getting a lot more measurements at sea on several expeditions.
I was on three or four, one to the Gulf of California, off California, North Pacific,
And I can't remember all the cruises.
There were just several that I was participating in at the time I was a graduate student.
And so finally I got my PhD.
1960, I think it was.
Of course, it was very important to get your reputation established, as it is in all fields of science, by publishing.
So I had gotten out a couple of papers at that time, too, just about the same time I was getting through my PhD and continuing the work at sea.
So I stayed in that for a few more years at Scripps as a research scientist.
I was on the staff for three or four years and felt

that that was very beneficial for me at the time, because I could take advantage of the instrumentation and setup, the organizational setup that I was familiar with at Scripps for a few years, to get a lot of work done to see, to get a lot of papers published, which I did.
So that kind of caught me up with things, and I suppose sort of gave me a reputation in the field at that time.
that still stays with me, even though I may not be as active now as I once was in that particular field, personally.
But about that time, I guess I was feeling a little bit of the need to diversify my own interests and test my own
fields of interest and what I really wanted to do for the rest of my life.
So I took an opportunity to go do something entirely different.
Not entirely different, but quite different from what I'd been doing.
In 1964, I took a
job in UNESCO in Paris.
Okay, one second.
Now, we've got a blank that's occurring between 60 and 64.
Okay.
Now, obviously, you were doing something between 60 and 64 besides writing papers.
Where were you then?
Right.
Well, I was at Scripps.
This is the period when I was, after my PhD, when I was on the staff at Scripps.
That's what I thought.
And was heavily involved with the heat flow work.
Okay.
This is when I went to see a lot.
And who was working in heat flow with you between 60 and 64?
Well, I...
I was essentially the principal researcher experience at that time.
At the same time, other institutions were getting involved more heavily, like Lamont and Woods Hole with other people.
John Reitzel was here at Woods Hole.
I don't know whether you know him.
No, I don't know him.
He was involved with people over several years.
He's not in the field anymore.
And then Mark Langseth at LeMond, who you may interview.
Well, I haven't been to LeMond yet, but I will.
He's about the same vintage as I am, and started getting involved.
Well, Maurice Ewing was an inventor of another type of instrumentation, similar, at LeMond.
And Mark Langseth was heavily involved in that, and I still have a lot of contact with him at LeMond.
about the same vintage as I was.
They were sort of doing an independent program over in the Atlantic.
It was the same kind of things.
I think we kind of had to jump on them at Scripps because Sir Edward Bullard had gotten the thing started in 1952 with Art Maxwell.
So we had a lot more measurements in the Pacific than we did in the Atlantic in the early 1960s.
And at the same time, the new geological ideas were coming along right then about the nature of these mid-ocean ridges and what they represented.
We didn't really have seafloor spreading back then.
So we were essentially kind of making measurements all over the place to understand the distribution of heat flow in conjunction with the geological features of the seafloor.
The big aseismic ridges, such as the Cocos and Tehuantepec Ridge, Gulf of California, which turned out to have high heat flow.

And Lennard, about the time, was very active in interpreting the East Pacific rise and how it represented a major mountain forming feature, which was going right up the East Pacific rise, coming from the South Pacific up into the Gulf of California, and then right up into the western part of the United States.
And the idea was that there were big convection currents going on down under
under the crust of the earth, and that these convection currents were bringing heat up, which we could measure heat loss through the surface.
And then this also, I think, our ocean work stimulated a lot more work on land at the same time.
I started to get involved with a land program, also, of heat flow measurements and scripts.

because Victor Bakke, who you may have talked to in the scripts, came there about that time, early 1960s, and brought his expertise, geophysical expertise, of doing work on land, and he and I started the program of making heat flow measurements on land.
I did never finish that.
I left Scripps before that time.
It was carried on by John Slater and Bob Warren and Vic Bakke.
Eventually published the work on land, showing the high heat flow continuation of the Gulf of California up into the western United States.
But my work between 1960 and 64 was essentially a continuation of the work I'd done there as a graduate student.
making heat flow measurements, tying it in with other seismic refraction work, other geophysical measurements, geological measurements, and see to understand these major geological features.
Now, were you teaching classes at Scripps then, too?
I wasn't teaching much.

This was one of the other things that kind of made me leave Scripps, I think, eventually, because there was this big dichotomy, I felt and still feel, existed at Scripps between the research staff, which I was a part of, and the...
and the academic sides of things, the teaching staff, and still existed scripts.
We don't have that here at Woods Hole, at least right at the present time.
I hope we don't get that, because it tends to divide people a little bit.
And I felt, although I had a lot of freedom in my shirts, that I didn't have much to say about the way the university is run or the teaching of students or anything like that.
I did help give lectures in some courses.
I was invited to do that and talked about it before.
Bill Menard taught a course.
I think Russ Raitt and others were teaching courses at that time.
But I was still fairly specialized at the time.
And I felt I needed some broadening of my own background.

So I took an entirely different tack at that time and went over to UNESCO in Paris in 1964, sort of at the urging of Roger Revelle and my other mentors at Scripps that there might be an interesting thing to do.
Sounds like a nice background.
Well, that's probably the fluorescent lights, but that's okay.
It's one of these things.
Before we leave Scripps and you go to UNESCO, I want you to make some comments about Scripps.
What was Roger Revelle like?
Roger was a very exciting person.
He was director at Scripps at that time, and had been for a number of years.
He had the ability to give you an excitement of the field of oceanography that nobody else, or very few others, were able to do at the time, I think.
Walter Monk could do that to some extent.
And Russ Ray, too, in his particular field of seismic refraction.

Russ, well, what I learned from Russ Ray, I'll just sort of ramble, and then we'll go on through this, is the real appreciation of good measurements of C. Russ was kind of a perfectionist, and I think still is.
He wanted good measurements and unambiguous data that he didn't want to be wishy-washy about the interpretation of.
So I think he
more than anybody else gave me an appreciation for the good quality measurements at sea.
And Walter Monk, I didn't know as well, because he was more involved with physical oceanography problems at the time than he was in geophysics.
And so I wasn't too close to him, although we were on the same floor at the same time.
He was more in oceanographic problems.
But I could see that Walter was thinking a lot about the quantitative aspects and theoretical aspects of oceanography and geophysics.
And I always had a feeling, a little bit, of being in awe of Walter when I talked to him, because he clearly had a much deeper theoretical background than I did and understood a lot about geophysics.
I think Walter, I don't know whether you interviewed him.
Yes, I did.
was attracted into the field also by Roger Revelle to some extent.
They both came to Scripps.
About the same time.
Temporaneously, I think.
Actually, Sverdrup was probably the person that attracted them.
Revelle maintains Walter Monk came there to meet a young lady.
That's his explanation.
That could be.
That could be.
I don't remember that history, because that was before I arrived on the scene.
And I didn't know Sverdrup either.
But I know they both benefited under his guidance.

Roger was the kind of a person who was very broad, and he understood many aspects of oceanography, and was always encouraging students to get involved and exciting them about the aspects of oceanography, wherever their interests might lie.
And I think his contribution to my education
was partly through his own research, which was in heat flow with Art Maxwell initially.
He wrote a lot of papers about the implications of these unusually high measurements of heat flow in the oceans.
And I benefited from those in my initial stages.
But he also contributed by directing me
and channeling me into the areas that he thought were fruitful, were going to pay off in the next few years, like heat flow or seismic refraction.
And so I'm very grateful for that, because I didn't know anything about oceanography at the time, and was able to follow that channel very, very good at that particular time.
So I considered Roger as a major contributor to the direction I took in my own research.
Besides being a very personable friend, he had me over at his house and introduced me to his family.
It was kind of a big family at Scripps at that time.
